title: Can court award the house to one person but force the other person to stay on the loan?
question: I am going through divorce in LA county in California. My wife is living in family residence since separation (more than a year) and I am renting. She is paying for mortgage for more than a year. The house is upside down and neither one of us can refinance the other one out. Can court award her the house because she is currently living in it and also has primary custody of our child knowing that bank will not remove me from the loan until there is at least 20% equity? In other words, can court force me to stay on mortgage loan until house builds equity for refinance, but award the ownership to her? If not, what will be court's decision in this case??
answers:
Yes, the family law judge can award your house to your wife knowing that the bank won't let you remove yourself from the loan, if that's the way your financial division works out.

As for what the court's decision will be, that's impossible for anyone on this website to know. Only a lawyer who's reviewed the entire case file and has all the facts disclosed to them can evaluate all the factors relevant to a property division, spousal support and child support. The parties' respective earnings, education, assets, debts, the length of the marriage, etc., and many other factors go into these determinations.

You're best off hiring a family lawyer.

This answer does not create an attorney-client relationship.

California divides Community Property equally between the parties. The judge has the discretion to determine what comprises each party's one half. It is generally impossible to tell how a judge will physically accomplish this before a trial.

Additionally, the judge has no power to make the creditor remove your name from the loan. The only way that can be accomplished would be for your wife to refinance and remove your name. However, it is difficult to see a judge trying to order a refinance while the house has negative value.

Finances of both you and your wife can play a major part in the judge's decision. It would be well worth your while for you to seek a consultation with a Family Law Attorney, and bring a full financial picture for the attorney to evaluate. However, keep in mind that the atty can only, even then, give you his or her best estimate of what "might" occur.
